Award.AwardTitle: Workshop on Quantitative Representation of Microstructures and Materials for Extreme Environments; Alexandria, Virginia; May 20-24 2019

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Workshop on Quantitative Representation of Microstructures and Materials for Extreme Environments will be held May 20-24, 2019 in Alexandria, Virginia. This workshop brings together leading experts in quantitative representation of microstructures and Materials for Extreme Environments. The workshop aims to develop tools and strategies to expand the field of materials modeling and data science, and expand their application to extreme environment conditions with integration of non-equilibrium physics. This award provides support for the meeting logistics. The expected outcome of the workshop is an accelerated roadmap to develop and manufacture materials to operate at non-equilibrium conditions. When applied at this scale, transformative research that relates processing to microstructure to properties quantitatively will lead to disruptive technological developments. The collaborative and open approach developed will provide a competitive advantage to the United States, in particular in aerospace and defense applications.

The goal of the workshop is to bring together researchers that (i) develop mathematical tools, (ii) expand existing models to more realistic conditions, and (iii) verify the outcome of the models and define the realistic environment of applications. Prospective attendees represent a diverse group of researchers with a variety of expertise and perspectives. Participation in this workshop is co-sponsored by this award and the Air Force Office of Scientific Research (AFOSR) program on Materials in Extreme Environments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Final Report on

Workshop on Quantitative Representation of Microstructures and Materials for Extreme Environments

Alp Sehirlioglu

Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Case Western Reserve University

 

The five-day workshop was held at Holiday Inn Alexandria during May 20-24th 2019. It included presentations from both NSF and AFOSR funded researchers. In addition to five days of talks, there were poster sessions with 25 posters most of them presented by students.

The workshop brought together leading experts in quantitative representation of microstructures and materials, and the researchers working in the Air Force Office of Scientific Research (AFOSR) Aerospace Materials for Extreme Environments Program in an effort to achieve a collaborative environment that identifies the current challenges, and discusses how to revolutionize the future through application of quantitative representation of microstructure and material in extreme environments encountered in Aerospace application. There were total of 140 registered attendees. The first day Monday May 20th had 113 attendees, Tuesday May 21st had 119, Wednesday May 22nd had 123, Thursday May 23rd had 119, and Friday May 24th had 95 attendees. 93 of the 140 attendees had oral presentations.

The attendees covered both national and international researches. There were researchers from 22 different states. In addition, there were researchers from Germany, France, South Africa and Turkey. The attendees included people from academia, industry, national labs, and federal labs including Air Force Research Laboratories. 30 of the 140 attendees were female.

The workshop brought together researchers funded by Division of Civil, Mechanical and Manufacturing Innovation (CMMI) of the Engineering Directorate of the National Science Foundation (NSF) and AFOSR Aerospace Materials for Extreme Environments Program. It aimed to lead a discussion in developing tools and strategies to expand the field of related modeling and data science, and expand their application to extreme environment conditions with integration of non-equilibrium physics. Each day included a lunch presentation by program managers from different federal institutions including NSF, AFOSR, DARPA, NASA and ONR. The workshop lead to successful integration of researchers funded by the NSF and AFOSR programs and as a result of effective discussions, there have been reports of researchers starting new collaborations both with each other and with researchers from Air Force Research Laboratories.

The initial budget was for $48,768 that included Hotel fees for $30,480 that included meeting break beverages and food both in the morning and the afternoon, as well as lunch. The cost also included the meeting room rental, audio and visual aid such as microphones, speakers, projector and speakers. The indirect costs were $18,288 at 60% indirect cost rate. After the meeting additional funds were requested to cover additional expenses accrued during the workshop. These include additional wireless microphones, additional speakers and a higher resolution projector and a bigger screen. Each wireless microphone was $125 per day. 2 of them for 5 days adds up to $1250. 2 speakers are $150 per day at 3 days, it adds up to $450. Projector and screen update was $175 per day for 4 days, adding to $700. The total of these changes are $2400. The service charge was $528 and taxes were $51.24 adding up to a total extra charge of $2979.24.
